Yuru Yuri is one of those shows I was curious about, wondering why it was so popular. I decided to give it a go, and I can't really understand why so many people like it so much.
My biggest issue is two things: The characters are incredibly bland and annoying, and it's not very funny... At least to me.
Honestly, it was difficult finding any of the characters likeable. The only two I enjoyed throughout the whole run were Kyoko and Akarin. Everyone else is basically a walking stereotype like Ayano, Yui, or Chitose. Ayano is your textbook tsundere and really loves Kyoko for no real goodreason. Sakurakou and Himawari are just there for the breast jokes. Chitose only exists to impliment some yuri fanservice... Do you see what I'm getting at here? Everyone feels like they're simply pawns to make an unfunny and predictable joke. It was so one-note and by the book that I had a hard time laughing at anything.


I really disliked Chinatsu in particular because she ended up being so unlikeable. A very stuck-up and pretentious girl who's only defining trait is hating Kyoko and being madly in love with Yui. I'm not exaggerating when I say that's what happens when the show tries focusing on her, one of those two things happen. Or maybe both. There also was a part in episode 11 that made me dislike her even more, but I won't spoil it. Nothing about her is a good character to me, and the show would have been much better if she wasn't part of the main cast.





Now for the jokes, which unfortunately don't land well most of the time. Like I said earlier, a lot of the comedy stems from the characters which are all very stereotypical so you can see what's coming a mile away. What's worse is that they like to really hammer in the same jokes over and over across the entire season. Was Chitose getting a nosebeleed and fantasizing about Ayano and Kyoko being together not funny the first time? Well too bad, because it's going to happen many, many other times! You can really tell what's going to come up just because it all is painfully predictable. There were a few times were they threw curveballs and made me laugh, but it was very few and far between. There's one joke in particular which just felt way too mean spirited, which is Akarin barely having any screen time despite being the supposed protagonist. It's a cute funny joke at first, but overtime it just ends up being kinda hard to watch because it feels like the world is against her and nothing goes her way.  There are even times where she doesn't appear for an entire episode just because of a short gag in the beginning. Maybe I'm looking too deep into it, but I really didn't find that funny and just became grating after a while.



So overall, I really wanted to like Yuru Yuri, but just ended up really bored and wanting it to be over near the end. The characters did absolutely no favors as they made the show very bland and predictable, and hardly any of the jokes landed for me.

Honestly nothing particularly stands out with this, but if you're watching it for what it is, it is perfect. A lighthearted and silly anime. Lacking complex characters and depth, this anime aligns the little it has to provide humour (this is how it's really spelled spellcheck!!) and simple stories that are brief without being underwhelming. This is by no means a masterpiece, but it is still a work of art. Pleasing to the eye, and warming to the heart.
Apparently reviews need to be longer, but I think this is enough to express my opinion. Thank you for reading my first review.

What does one expect when he starts watching anime about middle school girls which are starting an enjoyment club? Well I dont know what you dirty minds expected but I wanted to have fun and that exactly what I got, nothing less nothing more.
This show has no deep story, no character progression, but it has really nice moe art and sence of humor. It is best show to watch after something deep and challenging like  Steins;Gate, you will just turn off your brain and have fun.
It is based on short stories, situations and interaction between four main heroines and few other girls which areliving their normal middle school lives. 


Those main characters ( I really cant remeber any boy featuring in this show) are quite different, and so their interaction has quite funny element in it. few of them follow classic types like tsundere, yandere etc. but most of them are original (its basicaly because of their youth and naivety).


I dont think there is really anything more to add, if you want to just have fun based on spoken and visual humor, turn of your brain and enjoy, this is anime for you.


8/10 Would relax again

If you're wondering what Yuruyuri is about, the title really says it all. The girls go to school and do something "fun." The girls bring in some lesbian jokes in the premise.Outside of providing a silly, outrageous good time, that is. It's all deeply stupid and quite fun.
        Yuru Yuri is pretty pointless and episodic. There's no chance to make a compelling arc. A club the purpose of which is to facilitate the doing of nothing.
        The Characters of this show are simplysketched, and are distinctively cliche. Akari is the nice girl type with a "not so main character-ish" presence, Yui is the smart, cool one, Chinatsu is similar to Akari but poses a dangerous threat of sadism, and Kyouko is the energetic and irresponsible one and so on. Much fun is similarly had with the three tsunderes in the student council, and the glass girl Chitose, who often takes off her glasses to nosebleed-fantasize about her classmates. There's so little variation on the usual character themes that whenever there's any crossover it gets hard to tell characters apart. It takes a particular kind of viewer to enjoy something like Chitose's fantasies, during which things are pretty normal until she takes those damned glasses off, but if you're that kind of viewer, you're unlikely to find a funnier series with better characters than this.Characters are quickly and simply sketched, and are distinctively cliche. There's so little variation on the usual character themes that whenever there's any crossover it gets hard to tell characters apart. It takes a particular kind of viewer to enjoy something like Chitose's fantasies, during which things are pretty normal until she takes those damned glasses off, but if you're that kind of viewer, you're unlikely to find a funnier series with better characters than this.\n
      Yuruyuri Character designs, objectively speaking, are standard to the point of plainness - the way they are used being far more interesting than their appearance. Backgrounds, particularly the Yui's apartment and the Amusement Club room, are well-detailed and fully sufficient to their purpose, but they're given to little scene time to be called impressive. There's fanservice to be sure and plenty of naughty, but not dirty,particularly involves Himawari's boobie gags and Chitose's delusional fantasies\n

Going into Yuru Yuri, I thought that it was going to a slice of life anime with heavy yuri in the middle of it. I was kind of right, and in the process, I found one of my favorite slice of life animes.
Story:
There is no real story in Yuru Yuri. It has that Hidamari Sketch feel where you just see the main characters do whatever comes up, talk to each other and just live their lives. Pacing is a bit slow on the first couple of episodes and they didn't get down their comedic timing yet, but it picks up real quickly. Depending on thetype of person you are, you're either gonna love or hate the fact that nothing really happens. Me, I personally don't mind, as long as I laugh, it's all good, and you're definitely laugh. So it's an 8 for me


Art:

Art is great, each episode, you'll find another sort of anime-y face which will make of course, make you laugh. It's pretty simplistic in it's art, nothing too amazing, but that's good because it won't distract you from what you're suppose to pay attention to, which is the characters and the interactions. The characters all have vastly different hair styles with a different hair color so you can tell them apart easily, which is good since there's 8 main characters you follow. Not much to say from me, just loved the anime faces they make, 10.


Sound:

The seiyuu's do a great job to match the voices of their respected characters. Whether it be aloof, a tsundere, or a pervert, they do the voices well and it helps distinguish their personalities. The background music is pretty chill and sometimes silly which fits the anime, so I have no complaints. The OP and ED is pretty damn good, both catchy and the seiyuu's do a good job singing them. To me, 9


Characters:

As said before, they're all distinct due to hairstyles hair colors and personalities. You've got your typical aloof characters, tsundere girl, dumb character, "notice me senpai" character and all the sorts, but one character sort of rubbed me the wrong way and that's a character who imagines yuri between two characters. You will either tolerate it or sort of find it uncomfortable which I did because the yuri scenes happened pretty frequently in the early episodes and was pretty long. Thankfully, the whole yuri imaginations slowed that and made it better by making it less. Other than that, I still remember all the characters, I can name all of them and they're all memorable. Just cause they didn't know how to make their characters work together, I give it an 8.


Enjoyment:

Definitely one of my favorite slice of life animes, great comedy, fun characters and I can always just go back to a random episode if I feel like just seeing it again. Anyone can jump into it if they don't mind seeing a bit of yuri. Enjoyed the songs too, both very catchy and worth listening to cause it makes me dance. Fun anime, 9.

I began watching Yuru Yuri yesterday and so far it's pretty good.  The op is really catchy and very cute.  The art style is ok, it's really bright and cheerful, since this isn't much of a serious anime at all.  The character design is decent, the characters are really adorable.  All the girls are 13 and 14, middle school, and alot of them seem to be lesbians.  As far as I've seen, there are no male characters in this series.  The characters personalities are pretty decent. Akari is the good girl, Yui is the mature girl, Kyouko is theotaku, and Chinatsu is the innocent girl.  Chinatsu also looks up to Yui is a posisble romantic way.  Kyouko also makes Chinatsu cosplay as Kyouko's favorite anime character, Little Witch Miraku-run, since Chinatsu looks so much like Miraku.  It's just a cute school life/comedy anime with some yuri intentions in it.  If you like moe,  school life, or yuri then I recommend checking it out.

Despite the "Yuri" in its title, this show doesn't even come close to being a Yuri anime show. It's more on a Shoujou Ai side but there are no lesbian relationships here. 
[Story]: (7/10)
After finishing Middle School, Akari Akaza joins the the tea ceremony club along with her two childhood friends, Toshino Kyouko and Yui Funami. Soon, a 4th member joins named Chinatsu Yoshikawa.
Ok, doesn't that synopsis remind you of some slice-of-life show that you most likely have heard of or have watched already? I think it was that show from Kyoto Animation...That's right..K-On!. I really don't want to compare both shows even though thesimilarities are obvious so I'm moving on. 


The story of the show is.....Well....nothing. It's just a simple slice-of-life "cute girls doing cute things" kind of show except most, if not, all the characters are lesbians. Although, like I said in the opener, there are no lesbian relationships here so if you're here for that then this is not the show for you. There are occasional scenes where they would tease the viewers, showing the 2 characters being lovey dovey towards each other but that's it. The show will not go as far as dating. 


The comedy is what you'd mostly expect in a lesbian anime show..For example, Chitose having a nosebleed due to her yuri fantasies, Toshino being obsessed with Chinatsu, Chinatsu being obsessed with Yui, a lesbian tsundere acting like a tsundere. The question is are the jokes funny? Ehh, the jokes are decent but not the funniest.  


Most of my review will be on the "Characters" category so this section will be short. 

______________________________________________________________

[Art/Animation]: (7.5/10)

The animation isn't really anything special or even great..The background just looks so plain and it lacks details and the character designs are average at best. In short, it's decent. Then again, this is a slice-of-life show so..... 


What I do love is the "Akarin" intro. The Akarin intros are just so cute and every episode, I looked forward to it even though it was only about 15 or more seconds. 

______________________________________________________________

[Sound]: (8/10)

The soundtrack isn't really anything special either. The OST's that would play in the background when they're fooling around or when they're having a normal conversation aren't worth mentioning. Now the OP and ED theme song(s)


The OP theme song is Yuriyurarararayuruyuri Daijiken" by Nanamori Chu?Goraku Bu and the ED theme song is My Pace de Ikimashou" by Nanamori Chu?Goraku Bu. The OP theme song is not the greatest OP I've ever heard but it is damn catchy. Especially when the "Sakura saki" lyrics plays, that gets me everytime. The ED theme song is also pretty catchy..I just love Yui and Toshino's voice. 

______________________________________________________________

[Characters]: (8/10)

What you have here are 4 main characters who all happens to be lesbians. There are no boys in this world and everyone in this universe is a lesbian. Ohh, the joys of living in a world with no boys...I'm going to leave that to your imagination. Time to talk about the characters.. 


First, we have Akari, a protagonist who gets treated like a side character. She has a hair dumplings that can supposedly come off and can turn invincible when the word "Akarin" is shouted. I honestly feel bad for her character because of how she is treated in the show. Then there's Toshino Kyouko, a supposed protagonist of the show. She is an otaku, an energetic girl and she can't shut up for even a single second. Toshino = Best Girl! period. She's the main driving force of the show and she's just hilarious. Although, her jokes can get somewhat repetitive. She also "loves" Chinatsu. Then there's Yui, the calm, leader/senpai-like of the group. She's the one who keeps Toshino in check. Finally, there's Chinatsu, a girl who later joined the tea club. She's like an evil mini-yandere..She'll do everything to get close to Yui. 


Then there's a bunch of side characters that are forgettable NOT!. To be honest, I love all the side characters. Each of the side characters are funny and likable in their own way like Ayano's tsundere side and her puns that somehow makes Yui laugh, Chitose's yuri fantasy of Toshino and Ayano and her nosebleeds, Himawari and Sakurako's constant arguments. and etc. 

______________________________________________________________

[Enjoyment]: (8/10)

I'm a fan of Shoujou Ai shows and even though this anime didn't have any lesbian relationships, I still love this show. It's a nice slice-of-life to watch like K-On except they're all lesbians. 

______________________________________________________________

[VERDICT]

"Yuru Yuri" is a great slice-of-life series with a supposedly Shoujou Ai scenes. If you like watching "cute girls doing cute things" or you're a fan of it then this is a must watch show. Just don't hold your expectations high on the comedy because it's average at best. 


[OVERALL]: (8/10)


Pros:

+Great Slice-of-life show 

+A show Shoujou Ai fans can enjoy

+Average comedy

+All main and side characters are great in their own way


Cons:

-Plain Animation

"Cute girls doing cute things is truly the best thing that has ever happened to this timeline"
Let me preface this bad review by saying that i think most anime is trash but i hate myself for enjoying it all so much. Often i find the plot synopsis of most of animes absolutely stupid to no end. Yuru Yuri being a perfect example. A bunch of overly cute young schoolgirls hanging around drinking tea and bumbling about sounds like just another mediocre series that will print money for the studio behind it and make westerners even more embarrassed to confess they like the whole anime medium.
Iwas hesitant to start watching Yuru Yuri, but i'm sure glad i did. 3 seasons later and a newly gained interest for rum-raisin ice cream has solidified Yuru Yuri as my favourite anime. Who could think that an anime without a plot could be so captivating.


The characters are all quirky but consistent. The neatly written character development archs keeps you in your seat and the absolutely adorable girl-on-girl love scenarios warms my cold bitter heart to it's core.

At times it's really stupid and has made me laugh out loud at times. However, it's always in a perfect amount and has not gotten embarrassing once. The fact that they introduce a character as the main character and quickly forgets about her vital role is absolutely hilarious and shows that the studio and the people behind the series have a good amount of self awareness.


Yuru Yuri excels at what it's trying to be. It knows it's stupid and that's what makes it great.


What i'm trying to say is that i hate myself and that you should watch Yuru Yuri and treasure the time you have with this fun and adorable anime.


Also, if any of the story writers read this, i expect at least 3 marriage proposals in the next season.

【 The following is a review of : Yuru Yuri, Yuru Yuri: Happy Go Lily ♪♪, Yuru Yuri Nachuyachumi! (OVA), Yuru Yuri Nachuyachumi!+ (OVA), and Yuru Yuri San☆Hai! 】
Yuru Yuri is one of the best of its kind. Speaking for the moe genre and the absurd humor portion. If you think that one night, Teekyu and K-On got shit-faced, slept together, and had a bastard childーthis series would be their love child.
	• I initially dropped this series when it first started airing in 2011. The main heroine’s older sister, Akane, is rabidly obsessed to her imouto to a serial killer-like degree, so when Akari’s friendscome to pick her up from school and they accidentally wander into her sister’s room, seeing pairs of Akari’s panties splayed all over the place, grotesquely, and pictures of her everywhere and they are shock-still with terror. This moment is quickly swept under the rug with Akari making a punchline comment about not being able to find her underwear. 


	• At that point, I was disenchanted and didn’t the rest of the first episode a fair chance, because I thought that kind of behavior was being glorified, and maybe it was? There’s an on-going joke later after Chinatsu forces Akari to kiss her and she has dead, rape-victim eyes, so the anime has wandered into some pretty bleak fields of vision, with its humor.


	• I don’t know and frankly, I don’t care, because I like Yuru Yuri. I like the main cast of characters and their synergy with each other. It has really good visuals for its time and all of the girls are super cute, but have flaws like real human beings. You would appreciate the humor, if you like 4chan, trollsy, 4th dimension, stoner humor.


	• There’s not any REAL yuri in Yuru Yuri. Like, I said before, there’s a couple of scenes where the girls kiss and some of them obviously have crushes on other girls, but nothing happens. And watching this series makes you feel okay with thatーyou’re okay with the complacency and the surrealism and the chubby-cheeked quartet of school girls being goofy. 


	• That being said, seasons one and three have roughly the same rating for me. Liked them both, but Yuru Yuri: Go Lily happened and added an entirely new layer to the series. I already had Akari as my favorite character, but this season confirmed my attachment to her.


	• In the second season, there’s an introduction to each episode in which it’s pretty much like, “Hey, look! It’s our main character, Akari!” and then another character swoops in and over-shadows her because she has zero presence. 


	• You think that’s just a gag and nothing’s going to happen, not going to spoil anything, but you find out that all of those scenes are reoccurring for a reason. And there’s an episode that addresses it, and it made me cry, and Akari has a full-blown existential crisis over her identity as a wallflower. Remember, this is a moe show. So, wow. Just, wow.


	• Overall, Yuru Yuri deserves its spot as one of the kings, or queens (whichever you prefer), of moe. It’s definitely garnered a spot as one of my favorite “cute girls doing cute things” shows, along with Girls und Panzer. I give the first season of Yuru Yuri a 6/10, the second a 7/10, and the third a 7/10. The two OVAs that have been dropped are also jubilent little gems, I affectionately rated them both 7/10 as well! Please look past the initial creepiness and give it a second chance like I did, if Akari’s sister deterred you from watching.

- Hello, guys, finally I bring you my review of Yuri Yuri, starting with the story that could not be simpler, the story is basically the day to day of several girls, and although extremely simple, it is still very fun to follow the episodes. the work has very good moments of comedy, and this is what I admire in an anime, I admire when they transform something extremely simple, something fun and great to pass the time, anyway, there is not much to talk about the story of Yuri Yuri, it's a simple story but a lot of fun.
- On the technical side, doesnot have much to say, being a Slice of Life the technical part does not stand out so much, not that bad, on the contrary the technical part until it is good, the animation is decent, the visual is simple however flashy, the colors are vivid and well defined, in short it is a good technical part; now on the direction, this is a point that stands out in Yuru Yuri, the direction is excellent, it manages to create excellent comedy scenes, and the anime can be fun from beginning to end, of course I found some episodes weaker than others, however it goes a lot of the sense of humor of each person, but overall the direction is excellent.


- Soundtrack, this one is a difficult point to explain, because in general, the soundtrack is very good in some episodes, already in other episodes I thought it could have been better, varies a lot, but honestly until it is good, it does not have much to speak, even because soundtrack is not a strong of Yuri Yuri, what stands out even are the characters of the work.


- And finally we arrive at the strongest point of the play, the cast of characters, seriously the characters of Yuru Yuri are extremely charismatic, one more crazy than the other, and although some are stereotype, there are still some that stand out such as the character Kyouko Toshinou, undoubtedly the most charismatic character of Yuru Yuri, and also my favorite character, in short, the secondary characters are also very charismatic, in general the cast is excellent, they are captivating characters, charismatic and very fun, together with an excellent Yuri can be fun from beginning to end.

Ok, the first thing I should say, is that dogakobo's Yuru Yuri is a parody of the slice of life genre and the yuri in general.
All the characters must be taken as ridicule to the stereotypes that exist in the characters of the series of this genre, especially Akari.
The situations in this anime series are so surrealistic and ridicolous, nobody in the series take seriously the situations.
The most better developed characters, or better written, are Kyoko and Chinatsu.
Kyoko is a silly girl, her interestings are manga, anime, rum raisin, and a lot of fun, although it can be described as a selfish character, since shedoes whatever it takes to get her friends to do what she wants.


Next, we've Akari, the non-presence character. Her personality it's very beautiful, she is kind, considerate, innocent, a dreamer, and a good friend, but she is always overshadowed by the constant teasing of her friends, especially Kyoko.


Yui is the character without personality, has no development as such being a totally boring character, and that may be the reason why she always accedes to the whims of Kyoko, because without Kyoko, Yui is a character without identity or purpose.


Chinatsu is a very interesting character, because she looks like an innocent girl, but she isn't. She feels a pretty big attraction towards Yui, an insane attraction, since she practically wants Yui with her basest instincts. Her personality it's so variated, and this is the most interesting quality of her. It's so maniac.


The other characters are so charismatic, specially Chitose... Gosh, I love that girl.


With a lot of jokes and references to another series, this and the second season are the best in animation, because it's more a parody than a series of the genre.

Yay! Cute girls doing cute things now in lesbian middle school girls-edition! 
When I first found out about Yuru Yuri I was trying to look for something that is kind of against the norm of just presenting cute girls doing cute things. Something that would spice things up a bit. Of course my first intention for such a thing was not Yuri and I also legitimately thought at first that the whole Yuri-theme was just some joke despite the obvious title. 
Well let's take a look at what Yuru Yuri has in stock.
Storywise there really isn't anything happening which hasn't been done before - exceptfor maybe the seemingly homosexual main cast consisting of cute girls. This does not add any real substance to either story or change anything severely in character development. The worst thing which could happen is that one girl would attempt an obvious flirt but the comedy kicks in most of the time right after that to destroy any chance of an actual relationship happening between either of the characters. The whole Yuri-theme is mostly downplayed to mostly lame comedy instead of being the cornerstone for seriously romantic themes. But I doubt this was the creator’s intention. It was rather there - as said - for the jokes and the fan service which wasn't really a letdown for me personally since I didn't expect anything in terms of relationship building beforehand. Just at the end thinking about it, it was kind of a bummer but nothing severely.

In general the story sticks to the norm and so does the setting. We have a beach episode, a school trip, hot springs episodes, ... .People looking for your average school comedy set pieces and events will not be disappointed.


Looking at Yuru Yuri was one of the most pleasing things this show had to offer for me; Bright, cheerful colors as well as not really original but still adorable character designs and a constant level of quality. Not really much to praise or anything that would stand out in one way or another.


In terms of voice acting and soundtrack though, Yuru Yuri is way more confident with talented voice actresses and a - in my opinion - great and catchy opening as well as an ending theme which even ended up on my phone. As for the background melody Yuru Yuri plays it safer here but manages to set the mood quite well, maybe even because it is being so conservative at this topic.


Coming to the characters there is pretty much every archetype and trope involved in this happening. You have your silent and surprisingly unremarkable and heterosexual main character Akari who is in the role of the comical relief character and gets all of the writers bullying he had in stock. Not even lying there, Akari literally gets bullied by the writing of this show. From getting into accidents, not even getting noticed or simply ignored it was sometimes even painful looking at it. Then we have the hyperactive and manga obsessed Kyoko, who has a passion for manga and even works on own doujin and serves as the story's second main character with and endless stomach. Next up on the main cast is Yui Funami who is mostly your typical tomboy with a more cold side and last but not least my least favorite character of the bunch Chinatsu Yoshikawa. She is pretty standard in everything and seems to be into... forced stuff?


Overall the characters are neither the most original or best developed ones but still manage to come off as pretty likeable for the most part, in my opinion.


In conclusion Yuru Yuri is a pretty solid entry in the Cute-Girls-Doing-Cute-Things-genre. It had me laughing quite some time and it was highly enjoyable watching the silly main cast and what happened to them in the course of the time. Maybe the characters aren't really self-aware of their own sexuality yet - what is counter proven though looking at certain… Ahem delusions and things they are talking about - but it would have been nice to see any actual relationships happening instead of using the Yuri-theme to attract fans and reducing meaningful character development to merely one or two episodes at best.


Still. If you like those kind of shows and have nothing against some Yuri-themes and a girls-only-cast, make sure to give Yuru Yuri a try.

Yuru Yuri is dedicated to the Slice of Life genre, and while that may account for a lack of story depth, it isn't an excuse for a show such as this to have no depth whatsoever. 
It pains me to say this, as the show is really quite charming and likable, but essentially... There is no plot, it's just a "pleasant" 12 episode series of (very) mild Shoujo Ai, Comedy and SoL filler.
In terms of Art and Sound, as i expected from Pony Canyon, it was top notch! The animation style and audio couldn't be more fitting for presenting the unfortunately uneventful subject matter. 
Thecharacters, though some very typical anime stereotypes are all well introduced, and somehow without lots of back story, they're easily likable, acquaint-able, and... kawaii. What does this DO for Yuru Yuri? Well, this combination of top presentation and likable characters, with decent dialogue makes for a pleasant viewing experience. That's pretty much it though.


I've JUST finished watching and apart from a few glimpses of drama, it was all a bit of a blur, as there's nothing really to hone in on. 


The comedy is a bit bland and rehashed throughout, contrary to popular belief the show doesn't make any kind of moving/touching statement about homosexuality, it just utilities it as a tool to make up mildly amusing scenarios.


Who would want to watch this?

Well... If you're looking for something relaxing, something stress-free, a touch of humor and "cute girlies doing cute things" - BINGO! you've found your anime!

Slice of life is one of my favorite genres, and if you're reading this review then I assume you at least have some interest in the genre. If not, then I have to ask you: Why are you reading reviews for slice-of-life anime if you dislike slice of life?
But anyways, moving on.
Story: 8
Slice-of-life stories have to be rated on a completely different scale than most other ones. It's unfair to complain about lack of depth or the plot being boring and nonexistent when the whole purpose of a slice of life is to have no plot. In shows like this, all focus is on thecharacters, not the story.

With that, I think this show's story is a bit better than most. There's not a lot to go off of, but I personally like the idea of seizing an abandoned club room to form a fake club so the girls can hang out. Otherwise, the story is nothing special, even for the genre; the scene changes usually between the club room, the school, and every now and then someone's house. There are episodes where it'll change to a beach or Okinawa or something, but that's about it. Typical genre locations.

If you want a somewhat absurd but still more dynamic story, there is a doujin crossover of Yuru Yuri and Fate/Zero. Yeah, don't ask. Do go read it though, it's surprisingly not bad.


Art: 9

Cute girls doing cute things with cute expressions and cute school uniforms. Really, that's all there is to be said. No flashy special effects or cool looking designs, just cute. Everywhere.

If I'm not wrong, Doga Kobo is the studio behind Yuru Yuri. They aren't as well known as studios such as Madhouse or KyoAni, but their animation style is solid. I, for one, love the cutesy character design and the simplicity of it. The color palette isn't being abused to create girls with vibrant and strangely odd hair colors, everybody is normal. Just normal.

In short, there's nothing wrong with it. Points because it's cute, not a masterpiece because there's nothing special about it.


Sound: 8

While I'm not a huge fan of the opening and ending music, that can be foregone. With most shows, music is used during episodes to set the atmosphere and played during action scenes or montages or whatever, and with slice-of-life anime, it's generally just used to build up to a punch line. It isn't really something to be harped on, I found myself enjoyed most of the music from the show, and I especially liked the short music clips during the half-time.

I've never and will never be picky about sound. The only exception to this rule is when there's something definitely off about them.


Character: 9

"What makes a character interesting is their personality. What makes them unique is the way they interact with the people around them." It's probably been said before, but those are my own words. I believe it's true because if you go by personality alone, there will *never* be a character that is completely unique. There will always be many other "tsundere" characters, or many other airhead characters, or many other stoic characters, and it's no easy feat to design a character that is wholly unparalleled.

With that being said, the characters are cute. None of them really seem boring, although they aren't exactly in-depth. There's little quirks and traits that make them who they are, and if not then there's a relationship with someone else that makes them stand out. For Akari, her lack of presence. For Kyouko, her relationship with Yui. For Chitose, her OTP shipping (that causes nosebleeds) of Kyouko x Ayano. Yui is usually the "tsukkomi," but there's more to her than just reacting to the punchline.

All in all, I loved the characters. There's no need to have truly unique characters to have a good cast. As long as they all interact together and have at least some sort of defining trait, that's good enough for me.


Enjoyment: 10

Hey, I love slice-of-life shows, and this isn't an exception. When you need a break from all the dramatic action and supernatural, just pick up a show like this and relax. It works for me!

This show in particular wasn't anything new or amazing, but the characters are cute and it doesn't get boring (first episode of Lucky Star, anyone?). I thoroughly enjoyed it, and I'm looking forward to watching the next seasons and OVAs and specials and whatnot.


Overall: 9

It's nothing special, as I've said many times, but this show is worth a watch if you're a fan of slice of life. I found it cute, funny, relaxing, and surprisingly dark at times (episode 4, for example). Still, it was a good watch and I'm glad that someone recommended this to me.

What sound DOES a panda make?
Story:
I read somewhere that Yuru Yuri can be translated as "relaxed lesbians". That's pretty much what this is. It's a cute little slice of life comedy...with lesbians. That doesn't mean we get to see tons of fanservice or breast-grabbing or butt-touching, it's just the setting for this anime. There are a couple of girls that do have a crush on each other, which makes for some of the comedy, but much of it comes from the characters themselves, disregarding their sexuality. Actually, it's much tamer than I expected it to be, which I'm okay with. But putting the yuri baitaside, is it funny? In my opinion, yes.

8/10


Art:

It's moe-style. That should tell you everything you need to know, but writing nothing else would make this paragraph look pretty pathetic. There are a few cases of art shift, especially with the girls faces, which are hilarious. I liked it for its colorfulness and slightly wacky animation.

7/10


Sound:

When an opening is so damn catchy you sing it at work and make everybody around you give you weird looks, you've done it right. I usually bitch about random j-pop songs used for anime, but for a show like this, what would be more fitting? Same goes for the ending song, which is almost as catchy. The voice acting is fine, there was no role that I'd say didn't work.

9/10


Characters:

Are they stock characters? Probably. But that doesn't have to be a bad thing if they are used right and in this case, they are. Akari is so incredibly stereotype that she becomes an effective parody of a main character. Kyouko is a lot of fun, though she can be a bit too much from time to time. Yui is a great straight "man" to the madness and Chinatsu is a bitch in sheep's clothing, which is not groundbreaking, but not common enough to be boring. The side characters were likeable too. For some reason I especially liked Ayano, even though I'm anything but a fan of tsunderes (maybe it's because most are just terribly written?).

9/10


Enjoyment:

Yuru Yuri was a lot of fun to watch. I liked the comedy, I liked the characters, I liked the pacing and I even looked forward to watching/hearing the opening and ending, which is something I usually don't do. It was a good idea to divide the series into multiple 12 episode seasons, so you can portion it and not overdose yourself with it (what I surely would have done). Absolute recommendation for anybody who's looking for a slice of life and/or comedy anime. I'll only give it a 9 though, because if I DID watch more than 12 episodes in a row, the whole thing might grow stale on me sooner or later.

9/10


Overall:

8.4/10

You know, when you have a title with the literal translation "Easygoing Lesbians", it's kind of obvious what you're going to encounter.  Easygoing as in no serious plot, and lesbians as in yuri central.  With that in mind, let's get onto the actual review because long winded beginnings are stupid.
Story (7.01/10):  The story of Yuru yuri is about our fabulous main protagonist Akari Akuza as she begins her fabulous new journey into middle school with her second year friends, Kyouko and Yui.  At least, that's what I would say if it wasn't for the Akari's lack of presence.
To be honest, thisstory is nothing new/special.  The idea itself been done MANY a time by hundreds of other animes, and this show is no different.  There's no significant plot, since the whole series is episodic to all hell, and there is no real character development throughout the entire series, since no of the gags or characters actually change in terms of personality or how they act.  This series has the exact same formula as lucky star, Nichijou, Acchi Kocchi, GJ-Bu, Seitokai no Ichizon, etc.  That being said, whenever an anime is one of these slice of life's with no real meat in the story, you have to make it up in comedy, and that is exactly what this show does.


As I said before, this show has Yuri in it, and a lot of it.  All of it is in a perfectly comical sense, and that's what makes the show different from others.  (Sure there's the Kagami x Konata one in Lucky Star, but that's a non-canon thing.)  Unlike other slice of life shows, the yuri in this is blatantly there, and makes up the show as a whole, seeing as how we have some of the characters attempt to kiss other characters, and the obvious crushes that some of them possess.  


Other then that, the comedy that's not about the Yuri, (mainly Akari's lack of presence), brings the show full circle with its comedy as well, seeing as how I most definitely giggled and laughed when the funny parts showed up.


What I like the show as well, is the fact that this anime ended with a bang, literally.  It was that sort of over the top ending that didn't push its boundaries, while doing something completely unexpected.  All in all, while the actual story was nothing to be proud of in terms of originality, the comedy made it up in full.


Overview

+  VERY funny comedy (at least to my tastes)

+  Very blatant and obvious about what it was about

-   Not very original plot point.  (Like this would matter in the long run.)


Characters (7.75/10):  There is one thing that I think you should know if you're going to watch this.  This series is a Vaganime.  What is that?  It's essentially a term used to describe an entire anime cast, who is female.  Yuru Yuri, true to its name, has zero male characters, focusing mainly on the female gender, and the sexual relationships within said gender.  


Up first is the most important character in the series, Kyouko.  Or, as Ayano would say, TOSHINO KYOUKO!!!  She is the utterly the most important character of the show, due to the fact that she is one of the most sporadic and most random in the series.  The thing is, it works.  Her eccentric personality can only be rivaled to that of Haruhi and Konata, making her the show's favorite.  It is to the point that the show relies on her so much for pulling the show together, that they even make an episode on what would've happened if that personality that basically anyone who watches this show loves, was gone.  Personally, I find her to be quite entertaining and a rather interesting character due to how stupid and awesome she can be.


Up next is Yui, the cool character in the group.  Yui plays as the mature one in the group, always trying to reel in Kyouko from her unnaturally high tangents, as well as being one of the more "normal" members of the cast, since there aren't very many of them.  Regardless, she still plays a very good role of being a very good friend towards all of her friends, and supports them for whatever they do, unless it's a stupid thing that you probably shouldn't do.  


Chinatsu, as the more moe/chibi character of the show is presented to be that first year that everyone can adore.  She has a HUGE crush on Yui, (remember, this is a yuri show), and does whatever she can to impress her elder and is hopeful to marry her.  Nice to have dreams, ain't it?  Beyond that, I don't really see much in terms of her personality other than resenting Kyouko, but she is a nice addition to this cast.  


Now...before I mention the side characters, am I missing someone.  Hmm...let's see, Kyouko, Yui, Chinatsu...nope don't seem to be missing anyone.


Akari: "What about me?!"


Huh?  Who're you?"


Akari: "I'm Akari, the main character!  You know, the main protagonist?"


Akari Akuza is well...a joke, in a good way.  As the first character introduced, as the main character in the series, Akari is the happy-go-lucky girl who starts her middle school adventure.  Only to be shoved to the back of the cast and forgotten.  Throughout the series, she is told by the other characters that she is very...plain, and the fact that she has no real outstanding characteristics, so her presence is sort of, unnoticed.  (Seriously though, there are some members of the SUPPORTING cast that get more screentime than her.)  While I find this quite sad and hilarious at the same time, Akari is more or less that one character that everyone makes fun due to the fact that she goes unnoticed.  (I feel you, Akari)


The supporting cast in this series is one of the more enjoyable ones, I feel, due to the fact that we have such a wide range of characters that have differing characteristics, and represent different troupes, all of which have their special place in the series.  While some appear so often that they should be considered main, (i.e. Ayano and Chitose), and others that rarely appear and only serve to play a gag or two, (i.e. Himawari and Sakurakou), the supporting cast definitely fits the show's energy and purpose.  


Overview

+  Enjoyable main characters

+  Large supporting cast of various importance

-   Main character turned out to be a creator troll


Art and Sound (7.31/10 and 7.84/10):  The art is very light, colorful, and above all, very moe.  While the art itself is never overly detailed and generally on the white gradient side, the actual art style is one of the more key aspects of the show.  For starters, the biggest thing to note about how this show is moe, are the eyes.  Pretty much every character has these very large, round eyes, and unless you like moe, or don't mind moe, this will probably be your worst nightmare because every character is that cute.  


On a music note, the soundtrack of this music reflects the show very well, having a very catchy OST that repeats the show's name many, many times, involving an upbeat tune.  So upbeat in fact, that it is one of those songs you will never, ever get out of your head.  (Like Lucky Star or Haruhi.)  The ED was the same thing, just in a different tune and lyrics.  It's still upbeat and happy, much like the show it comes from, and is definitely a plus for the show.  


Overview

+  Nice amount of detail on art

+  Not overly complicated

+  VERY upbeat tracks

-   Extremely moe art style.  (This minus is only for those who don't like moe.)


Personal Enjoyment (8.88/10):  I admit, I'm a guy, and I enjoyed this wayyyyy too much.  While I was watching this, I really enjoyed how well executed the comedy was, as it was a nice balance between absurd comedy, yuri, and the actual plot line.  Regardless of my previous statement before about the show not having an original idea, I liked this show a lot due to how enjoyable this was.


Slice of life comedy shows are one of those shows that you can watch without any remorse, as you can just watch one episode, and pick up a week later, without forgetting the plot.  Personally, I liked how the series presented itself in a nonchalant matter, and I throughly enjoyed it all the way to the end.  I recommend this series to anyone who wants to just sit down and enjoy a pointless anime without any plot.  A good stress reliever I find.  However, unless you're not a fan of...


- slice of life shows 

- comedy shows 

- shows without any male characters period 

- yuri

- yuri fantasies

- moe

- moe comedy

- or a hyper energetic girl that steals the whole show...you will not like this at all.  (Seriously, if you don't like any of the mentioned things above, this isn't something you'd like.)


Overall score: (7.32/10)

Before watching Yuru Yuri, I first had to get through the tongue twister title. Ahh, but after that, I was already watching the first Akari~~~n opening. With that said...Hajimaru Yo (始まるよ)!!
Let's begin with those that are learning Japanese  I rate Yuru Yuri a 2/5.JAPANESE LEARNERS (2/5) Easy to Understand)


Fortunately, this anime is easy to understand without subtitles if you are at the intermediate or above level, there will be some advanced words or grammar phrases that will actually be used, and you should have no trouble watching this anime without subtitles. If you are a beginner Japanese learner, you will learn a lot of phrases and words without the subtitles so use this anime as an excellent learning tool.


                                                STORY


The girls want to start a club. They get a club. They get members. The end. That’s the story, but where do does 12 episodes actually take us, though. I like to think of Yuru Yuri as one of those Japanese Cop dramas where every episode is different yet gives us a little bit of a plot. Unfortunately, if you wanted a good story like a Shonen Jump anime, you won’t find one here. However, one should not watch the anime because of that reason alone. Each episode is amazing and unique in its own way. There is one episode where the girls go to the beach and one where they go to a hotel in Kyoto. This is how the anime is presented. Although you won’t get a story, you will get plenty of laughs along the way.


                                               ART/ANIMATION


Ah, how I adore cute anime characters. The good thing is that Yuru Yuri is not short of any cutesy-want-to-squeeze- characters. I also love how each character is drawn. They are drawn perfectly to fit their type, except probably Kyouko, who is drawn cute but is a total crazy girl. I will say however not to expect any awesome cgi or whatnot because the animation is typical of your regular slice of life anime.


                                               SOUND


Upon writing this review, the only music I remembered where the opening and ending song and those were pretty darn good. Actually, they were so good that I downloaded the songs. Aside from the theme songs, I didn’t think that any of the anime songs were of memorable nor of any particular interest.


                                                CHARACTERS


Lesbians. Lesbians everywhere. This is where this anime truly shines at. The characters all like another character and they show jealousy for each other, which is hilarious.


Each character has her own unique personality. From the clumsy Akari, adorable Chinatsu, and the nosebleed crazy Chitose, we are given a lot of characters to love and hate in this anime. If it wasn’t for these characters, I’m afraid that this anime would have been a disaster.


                                             ENJOYMENT


Funny characters and an amazing opening and ending theme song is what keeps this anime so great in my book.  The story and sound are lacking, but I think that since this anime is a shoujo-ai and slice of life anime, none of those things are particular needed, but they are welcomed. Also, if you know a lot about Japanse culture, then you will most certainly find puns and mimicrys everywhere. I laughed on every episode because of them. If you enjoy any slice of life or shoujo-ai anime and don’t care about the story, I recommend you give this a watch.

Cute comedy! 
This was a great sitcom type show about an all girl cast (really I think there might have been one background guy that mad an appearance in season 2) who basically make their own club and have little interactions with other girls in the school. They develop some "interesting" relationships. Overall very light and easy to watch, although season 3 does get a bit touchy/feely, recommend watching all of it if you do decide to take this one on. 
STORY:
Well like I said this is a sitcom there are lot of random episodes like one where everyone just goes on dates and onewhere one of the main characters goes back in time... Some things blow up and some girls have a bunch of fantasies that makes her nose bleed. If you watch all the seasons and start to like all the characters then really the little story that is there will be good enough. I felt like the first two seasons were full of great ideas with funny things happening in each episodes plot. Then once they get to season 3 they find a way to conclude it on a really happy note so you won't be wondering what really happened. A very satisfying feeling instead of the "omg wtf just happened" feeling...


ART:


Cute. Yeah it was really cute the way they made this anime, the reactions of the characters and different personalities and showcased well by the artists. And I really like the colours!! The colours they choose to use in an anime really sets the overall mood and with Yuri Yuri its all bright, cute, girly colours. Each character has a different coloured hair and when I think about the anime I think pink, yellow, light blue, really appealing.


SOUND:


I really liked the songs they choose, I think I must have watched the opening majority of the time since I liked to hear it again and again. Puts you in a really happy mood and sets you up for the show pretty well. All the voices were unique to each character, nothing seemed out of place.


CHARACTER:


This is what the show is really about! It's like watching Friends or Seinfeld but about a group of teenage girls in a club house who drink tea and do random stuff together. I think its pretty cool looking back on it because they really incorporated so many different personalities of girls into the show. They area all so different that you can associate traits from girls you know to each of them. There are four main characters who are basically a confident tom-boy, a creative, a creepy-cute girl, and a cute-normal girl (with not much presence but everyone likes her anyways). They balance each others personalities really well and then the dynamic between them and the other 5-6 girls in school (and some of their weird sisters makes each episode really easy to watch. I personally like to watch shows because of the characters and their relationships so I think this was a great show because of it.

Akarin! Haaaai~ Yuru Yuri Review Hajimeruzou!
Yuru Yuri or Easygoing Yuri is a story about four junior high school girls mostly spending their time in the Amusement Club. What is the Amusement Club you ask? The Amusement Club is where these girls are having fun and mostly do whatever they want. 
Pretty much like Lucky Star, Kiniro Mosaic, and other Moe-Slice-of-Life animes, Yuru Yuri does not have a deep storyline or eye-gazing character actions throughout the series. What makes Yuru Yuri worth to watch then? As the title suggests, Yuru Yuri will feature some lesbian scenes that is not overly sexualized or anything like that. Thesescenes are pretty cute and funny at times and the character behaviors really shine through to bring us watchers some good comedy.


Story : 7

With having no deep storyline or anything out of ordinary, I believe Yuru Yuri should get a lower rating than 7. But then again, it isn't quite fair when you compare the story of Yuru Yuri with the story of Sword Art Online, it's like you compare oranges to potato chips. With that being said, I decided to give Yuru Yuri's story a 7 because it just seems the fair thing to do.


Art : 7

The artwork for the series is okay. Not too much but not too shabby as well which in my opinion is fine for a Moe-Slice-of-Life type of anime. It's colorful at times which is essential for the series.


Sound : 8

The OP and ED songs was stuck on my head for some while. It has a really catchy tune that probably you can sing along before the anime really starts or really ends. It's also really cheerful which fits in the genre.


Character : 9

Yes, I am a total sucker for moe girls and if you're the same as I am then I'm pretty sure you are going to enjoy it as well. Almost all of the characters inside Yuru Yuri is full of moe and is very different from each other. From first glance, I can already differentiate which girl is which despite having a huge lineup of girls in the series. Some character behaviors are unique or maybe very unique which is really funny at times. 


Enjoyment : 9

The comedy and character behaviors being fresh and new, I really enjoy watching Yuru Yuri and hoped there will always be a continuation of it (which is impossible I know). The moe element also helps me enjoy watching the series over and over. I wished Yuru Yuri would put a bit of reference to other anime though or it would've been perfect.


Overall : 8

Yuru Yuri can be confusing if you are pretty new to watching anime, but overall it is a very enjoyable series if you watch them all. For the frequent anime watchers, Yuru Yuri can be one of the anime that brings you a smile and a laugh when things in life gets a bit rough.

When it comes to cute girls doing cute things (CGDCT) metagenre, Yuru Yuri is one of the tops. Story, as usual, is pretty much nothing. It's just bunch of cute girls going on about their daily lives. But Yuru Yuri is not failure of enterntainment like almost all others in this metagenre, since it is so funny. One of the very few animes that make me literally laugh out loud every single episode multiple times, it's just golden. Production values are very good, so it is not failing on execution aspect either. As always in this metagenre, characters are the deciding factor since show isbuilt completely around their interactions. And this is where Yuru Yuri steps up the game. 


Characters are actually extremely generic in the sense that every CGDCT has pretty much the same character types. You get the hyperactive idiot, bland sensible girl, big sister type, mild and meek one, and assortment of supporting cast. Such it is in Yuru Yuri, too. It's just that the joke timing, voice acting, expressions and how jokes fit the characters so perfectly. Yuru Yuri avoids the common pitfall of attempting to actually develop the characters or give them surprising new dimensions. It's 100% pure refined fun instead. It is competely unapolegic about being yet another CGDCT and even makes fun of how generic it is by partially driving the stereotypes to brink of hyperbole. That is why they are so good. They completely fit the comedic fun of the show without slipping even once to moralization or some kind of lecturing about life's realities. Simply do away with such things and insert another dose of pure fun.


Oh, and one brilliant comedic effect this show frequently uses is showing a side of characters to viewer another character doesn't know, then having those interact in a way where the other character is completely oblivious to the true meaning and intention of another character's actions which viewer of course knows. Confusion and chuckles abound.  


The title implies some heavy Yuri, and this is where show clearly makes fun of itself. For one, there are no males in the entire show which is a joke in itself. Secondly, yuri action happens only in delusions of one character. The rest of yuri-ness is so completely overboard in hard to explain way, that it simply becomes part of characters. If you are looking for gay girl romance, forget it. Let's just say I ignored this gem of a comedy for long time, expecting just that plus some boring SoL with light comedy here and there. Don't make my mistake: if you want fun times, just go and watch this!

I like Yuru Yuri, although I'm not a comedy fan, because it makes me laughs sometimes -I find specially hilarious Toshino Kyoko- and I see all the characters as "kawaii lesbians". Also, I think it's great that you can ship anyone with anyone. What I don't like about the show is the ostracism Akaza Akari suffers; I know it's super common in comedies for certain characters to be ignored or bullied without a reason, but I really can't help to hate that.

Okay, as far as cute goes, this is anime is cuter than a speckled puppy riding a unicorn through toyland.  But does it make for a good anime? Let's find out, this is YuruYuri.
Story: 5/10
Does this even have a story? Well, yes and no.  It's a slice of life anime, so it follows the lives of a group of middle school girls who join clubs, do club activities, and hang out with their friends.  Now I know what you're thinking: "This has to be borderline pornography with a title like YuruYuri..."  Well, it's not.  The moments of yuri that arein it are meant to be comedic and ARE very funny.  It does have a few cliche episodes, which is probably the reason I rated the story a 5/10.  I don't know what it is about anime, but come on, does every anime REALLY need a beach episode!?  Over all, it doesn't really follow a plot, so the story isn't it's strongest aspect, but it doesn't need to be, the characters are what pushed this show forward.


Art: 8/10


Well, I'm a sucker for cute girls, and the art is absolutely adorable.  Sometimes it looks a little weird, you'll know what I'm talking about if you decide to give it a watch.  The colors are bright, and honestly, the character designs made me smile.


Sound: 9/10


First of all, the OP and ED are AWESOME! If you don't like them when you hear them at first, you will by episode 3 or 4, they grow on you like crazy.  The voice acting is also very good as well. Though Ayano calling Kyoko "Tashino Kyoko" all the time sounded a bit weird to me, I can't say I didn't find it cute.


Characters: 9/10


Since this IS a character drivin show, the characters needed to be intersting in order to keep you entertained, and damn, did it do a great job.  All the characters are interesting and funny.  The four main cast made me laugh so hard half the time it was difficult to read the subtitles.  The supporting characters are all equally as interesting and even getting an episode or two dedicated to them.  In my personal opinion, it's the main cast's relationships with the supporting characters is what made them all so memorable.


Enjoyment: 10/10


Now, I enjoyed every single second of this show from begining to end.  When it first started I figured it was going to be another slice of life anime that went through all the regular cliches.  Don't get me wrong, this show has a few of the cliches in it as well, but every episode is hilarous.  I pretty much marathoned this (you'll notice I finished it within 2 days) because I couldn't stop watching it, only thing stopped me from marathoning it all in one sitting was the fact that I had to get up for work.  This show was a great ride and I was hooked from the first episode.


Overall: 8/10


All in all, if You like SoLs this will probably find it's way into your favorites.  The story, or lack there of, is entertaining, and the characters are hilarious.  Honestly, I'd highly recommend you give this show a watch.  It truely is, in my opnion, what a slice of life anime should be.

This review will be covering BOTH seasons of the series
I sat around thinking for a while how I'd go about writing a review for Yuru Yuri, or in that case, any slice of life moe series.  When it comes down to it, they're all the same thing.  A bunch of girls run around doing school stuff and being friends.  A-Channel, Lucky Star, K-On!, and those are just the main ones.  It's then when it became obvious that the reason one mainly enjoys these kinds of series is the characters and their interactions with one another.  So far, I feel YuruYuri portrays these interactions better than any other series in this genre.


-  In terms of the story, there isn't a whole lot to say.  If you've seen a slice of life moe series, then you already know exactly what to expect.  Cute days at school, cute days going out, cute days at the beach, and all that fun stuff that you absolutely love in this genre.


-  The art in Yuru Yuri has to be one of the best I've seen in the genre.  There weren't any points when I felt the animation was being lazy.  All of the characters were animated beautifully and were full of movement, especially Kyoko of course.  I didn't once see an image that made me feel as if they were taking the cheap way out.


- The music that's played throughout the series doesn't entirely stand out, with the exception of the character songs that play during the commercial cutaway point in the middle of each episode, and the Opening and Ending songs for both seasons, ESPECIALLY season 1's opening song which is one of the catchiest songs I've EVER heard. 


- The characters are definitely what make this series worth watching.  Each character has their anime stereotype trait, and they play their parts perfectly.  there's the hyper one, the cute one, the mature one, the tsundere one, and so much more.  The interactions between the characters are very funny and to be honest, this is the only series (other than the currently-airing Watamote) to make me actually laugh out loud, and that's thanks to these characters having excellent dialogue and getting themselves into hilarious situations.  My favorite interactions are usually between Ayano and Kyoko, which often results in Chitose removing her glasses and having a yuri fantasy about the two of them, which always gets a great laugh.


-The enjoyment factor of this series is very high.  Comparing it to other Slice of Life moe series, I must say, the amount of jokes that this series throws at you is very high, and a majority of them hit bullseyes.  Compared to series like K-On! or A-Channel, where the jokes aren't highly consistent throughout the episodes, if you're looking for something that's straight up comedy and nothing else, this is it.


Overall, this anime scores high across the board for me.  It offers fun episodic stories with incredible visuals, catchy music, fun, adorable characters, and the addictive-ness to keep you watching more. I say this series is certainly deserving of being one of the best Slice of Life moe series out there and highly recommend it to anyone who loves cute anime girls, comedy, and fun.

Al principio creí que era un anime yuri por el nombre, de hecho, lo comencé a ver por que estaba buscando animes yuri para ver, pero me encontré con una agradable sorpresa, un anime relajado de recuentos de la vida con toques de comedia y yuri ligero, cada personaje es muy agradable y te encariñas con cada uno de ellos, en especial la protagonista, que aunque dice no tener atención en el anime, es uno de los mejores personajes por sus reacciones ante las cosas que le suceden, seguida de el resto de los miembros del club de te y sus locuras, la primera ysegunda temporada son las mejores.

Yuru Yuri is a must for those who like cute slice of life comedies and just love to watch a bunch of girls enjoy their afterschool together; it would probably not add anything new to your experience of this genre (except for a big and actually entertaining love polygon), but it won't fail to make you giggle during all the 12 episodes.
The story, as always, is very simple: the four girls that compose the (unofficial) Amusement Club hang out in the club room, visit each other's houses, go to the beach, have fun with the girls from the student council, etc...; the characters are alsopretty standard, with the exception of Akari as the protagonist with no presence whatsoever, a fact that's paradoxically remarked constantly throughout the series, even in some "break-the-fourth-wall" instances. What is particular about Yuru Yuri and adds quite a bit to both story and characters is in fact the yuri announced in the title, which touches nearly everyone and affects nearly every relationship in the show: probably in real life this long chain of crushes (Chinatsu loves Yui, Kyouko loves Chinatsu, Ayano loves Kyouko and so on) would destroy the group but here its presence actually strengthen the bonds among the girls; there is a slow but steady evolution in the show where everybody gets gradually closer to each other thanks to it, although it's probably better executed in later seasons where for plot reasons the "improbable couples" episodes are more frequent, but anyway it's evident that all of them simply really like to spend time together despite and/or thanks to all the different love interests within the group.


On the technical side, the art is good and all the characters are drawn cutely, as expected from this type of anime (and they sure were good at creating the horrendous Chinatsu drawings, it has to be said, they were genuinely terrifying); the background music is ok, nothing special, and the opening song is quite catchy.


In the end Yuru Yuri is a very good choice if you're entertained by cute girls doing cute things and you're not annoyed by girl love, of which you'll have plenty, I can assure you.

To say Yuru Yuri should be taken seriously, is like telling a vegetarian to eat at McDonald's. Yuru Yuri is not just over-the-top, it's completely mad with a side order of bonkers. What I'm getting at, is that Yuru Yuri is insane, and that's exactly what it needs to be in order to stand out.
Yuru Yuri is about four girls who take over the tea club room at an all-girls school because nobody uses it anymore and hi-jinks ensue. Before you write this off a moe Haruhi rip-off, I will remind you that Yuru Yuri doesn't have a story so messy that it makes whata tornado does look like the work of a Cleaning-Nazi, or much of a story at all. The description I gave you is the extent of the plot, and is really more of a set up to the events that happen throughout. The story really works, because it fucks around at any and all given opportunities. The title is the first sign, because anything that has "Yuri" in the title, aside it being straight-up hentai, is not going to have any serious cards in its deck. If that doesn't do it for you, then allow me to tell you, the second joke in the series is a Big-Lipped Alligator Moment. Now, when you pull one of those that early in the series, that says you're not fucking around when it comes to fucking around.


This series is all for fucking around, and that's exactly why it's worth watching. It's a series that's trying to make you laugh, and each attempt is so over-the-top, and well-executed, that you can't help but laugh. The best part of it, is most of the jokes are self-aware and self-parody, and it's all so insanely cartoon-ish that you just know to not think about this in a serious  light, because it certainly isn't. It also uses irony to its advantage, the biggest example I'll get to later, and it's not smug about it, rather it's just as loopy as the rest of the humor. The jokes are so unpredictable and immersive that, even though you think it can't get any funnier, it somehow manages to do so, so basically Yuru Yuri is to fucking around what Serial Experiments Lain is to fucking your brain.


The thing about the story is, it's not afraid to evolve itself either. In the midst of its humorous crusade, it looks at itself and decides to mix up the formula a bit. It takes its humor to new heights, even including some dark humor near the end, so the characters aren't the only ones experimenting in this anime, the anime itself experiments with itself as well, which means that you are allowed into the science lab when you're residing in the loony bin, despite not getting access to any of the sharp tools. The best example of this is in the second-to-last episode, where one of the characters is out of character because they hit their head and doesn't sexually harass a character she usually does, and the other character gets upset about it. "Wow" I thought. "Not only is this some seriously funny shit, this is some good characterization."


The characters themselves are just as crazy as the story, more-so perhaps. They're each a style parody of characters of the genre, and are willing to take whatever joke they have to its new extreme. You could say a lot of the humor comes from character interactions and implications that are blown out of proportion. As established already, there is yuri in the show, if the title didn't tip you off, but it's not perverted, as much as it is both adorable and fucking hilarious. The humor keeps moving to more levels of funny, but it never loses its charm, and that's why it works. However, sexual orientation jokes are not the only ones the characters partake in. There are a lot of jokes about the character's main traits that are funny in more ways than one. Now, the biggest irony in the show deals with the main character, Akari. She is the butt-monkey of the series because the rest of the cast always point out she is not a very memorable character, making her one of the more memorable characters in the show, making each joke all the more funnier. The entire cast is very well-developed, and well-characterized and are willing to make jokes that characterize the series.


So far, I have been saying good things about this show, but what about the bad? Well, for starters, the music and art are seemingly generic. The art especially has this problem, because it has just decent backgrounds and decent character designs. Now, I have said mundane artwork works with series before, but that's not the case here. They worked, because it reflects the nature of the show's normality, and there's nothing normal about Yuru Yuri. It just feels like it could have tried harder in the art department. As for the music, it mostly feels unimportant. Yes, it's very good, but it doesn't feel like it wants to be noticed. That is, aside from the catchiest opening theme this side of Working!!, thanks in part by the studio that made it Dogakobo, who only other previous work I've seen (Myself;Yourself) also had a very catchy opening. The ending is also quite good, though not as catchy as the opening.


The story also has some problems. You see, while it's not afraid to experiment with what it has and reaching new heights with it, it is afraid of expanding to new territory. It feels like it only wants to parody the specific genre it's in and hardly anything else, and I feel an opportunity was missed to  gain more jokes out the whole experience by limiting the material it parodies to what it knows. Though, I suppose if the nice people who help you at the asylum won't let you near the pointy objects, asking for a bulldozer to expand your territory is really pointless. Another thing about the story I don't like is the habit of bringing up plot points and then never mentioning them again, or in layman's terms, having too many Big-Lipped Alligator moments. Don't get me wrong, I love a good Big-Lipped Alligator moment, but this series abuses how many one can have before it starts to get irritating. Still, this doesn't have a very big effect on the rest of the story, and you can still enjoy it all, but it is quite bothersome at some points.


Overall: Yuru Yuri is fun and enjoyable. The amount of self-parody is uncanny and in good proportion. If you're looking for something mindless and funny, than this is it. Yuru Yuri really knows what it is, and what it is, is totally, mouth-breathingly, paste-eatingly, chasing the girls around the playground with a piece of pooingly stupid. And I wouldn't have it any other way. 8/10

Yuru Yuri is one of the best slices of life i've ever seen, my second favourite in fact. The comedy is super hilarious. It will ALWAYS crack you up. The art-style is super moe and the characters are amazing, each one of them is super lovable and they all have their own perfectly defined style. regarding the plot, well it's what you would expect from a slice of life anime, but this one takes a lot of continuity to all the events that occur during every single episode and the newest season is really developing the yuri factor that wasn't quite used how it should'vein the first two seasons.\n
Even if you don't like moe stuff, you gotta check Yuru Yuri out, you'll legit laugh until your lungs stop working.

I really liked this series, but my only complaint is the romance. I was hoping there wouldn't be so much romance, but if you are looking for a cute & funny slice of life anime and don't mind the romance, then you might enjoy Yuri Yuri.

My rating is dependent on my enjoyment of Slice of life comedy's.
Yuru Yuri, is similar to most Slice of life animes centralised around girls. But the thing that made it unique, was that it doesn't focus on a single group. Instead it focused on 2 groups, and gradually introduces new characters who are all quite interesting in their own way.
I also enjoy how similar some aspects are to Danshi kokosei no Nichijou, Like the would be protaganist becoming less and less important.
The Characters are all quite interesting and weird. Kyouko was definately funny and enjoyable to watch. Chitoses Fantasy modes are funny. Even Chinatsu whoI thought was going to be annoying, ended up being quite entertaining.\n\n
The art style matches the characters, and the voice acting is pretty good.\n
I enjoyed it alot and had moments where I was laughing so hard my stomach hurt. \n\n
Overall I enjoyed it to the max.

Story (8): This is the story summed up: 4 middle schoolers who hang out in a tea room and have fun. If you like Lucky Star, you will also like Yuru Yuri.
Art (9): Although there is no shading, the lineart makes up for it by, like, a lot. The artist draws hands amazingly.
Sound (8): The themes are just as cheerful and fun as the anime itself, and the voices match the characters' personalities perfectly.
Character (10): The characters have cute designs, and none of them are Mary-Sues (a female character who has absolutely NO flaws and everyone love her. You won't find any in Yuru Yuri.).
Enjoyment(10): I like that how each episode is similar yet different. Also, I enjoy the preview that one of the characters gives a preview for the next episode at the end of each episode.\n\n
Overall, I give this anime a 9 and I recommend it! :D\n\n
